articles.headline: How Jeff Zucker Is Seeking to Reshape CNN
articles.snippet: After nearly two years at CNN, Jeff Zucker is trying to raise ratings, partly by emphasizing just a few stories a day, rather than delivering an all-encompassing report of the headlines.
articles.abstract: After nearly two years at CNN, Jeff Zucker is trying to raise ratings, partly by emphasizing just a few stories a day, rather than delivering an all-encompassing report of the headlines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeff Zucker, the president of CNN Worldwide, seemed to be having a blast Wednesday evening at a party for a new original series. Perched on the arm of a chair, he watched intently as a magician performed tricks with coins, cards and a Rubik’s cube.

articles.headline: Ways to Protect Yourself After the JPMorgan Hacking
articles.snippet: Consumers can lessen the risk of financial harm to themselves from big data breaches like the one at JPMorgan Chase.
articles.abstract: Consumers can lessen the risk of financial harm to themselves from big data breaches like the one at JPMorgan Chase.
articles.lead_paragraph: The numbers are shocking: Personal information from 76 million households may have been compromised as part of the cyberattack on JPMorgan Chase. That is the equivalent of two out of every three households in the United States, though a small portion of those affected may be overseas.

articles.headline: Dallas Hospital Alters Account, Raising Questions on Ebola Case
articles.snippet: While officials in Texas assured the public the disease had been contained, the White House sought to calm Americans’ fears about Ebola entering the country.
articles.abstract: While officials in Texas assured the public the disease had been contained, the White House sought to calm Americans’ fears about Ebola entering the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Health officials’ handling of the first Ebola patient diagnosed in the United States continued to raise questions Friday, after the hospital that is treating the patient and that mistakenly sent him home when he first came to its emergency room acknowledged that both the nurses and the doctors in that initial visit had access to the fact that he had arrived from Africa.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Michael D. Shear and Abby Goodnough

articles.headline: Beware of Shifting Options Within Medicare Plans
articles.snippet: Open enrollment for Medicare starts Oct. 15, and offers older Americans a dizzying array of health care options.
articles.abstract: Open enrollment for Medicare starts Oct. 15, and offers older Americans a dizzying array of health care options.
articles.lead_paragraph: For millions of older Americans, it is time to sift through the mind-boggling array of Medicare plans.

articles.headline: Justices Weighing Wages for After-Work Screenings
articles.snippet: A class action brought by Amazon warehouse workers asserts that their employer should pay them for the time they spent waiting to undergo security checks.
articles.abstract: A class action brought by Amazon warehouse workers asserts that their employer should pay them for the time they spent waiting to undergo security checks.
articles.lead_paragraph: After his 12-hour shifts at an Amazon warehouse in Las Vegas, Jesse Busk says, he and 200 other workers typically waited in line for 25 minutes to undergo a security check to see whether they had stolen any goods.

articles.headline: A Scramble to Acquire for Drug Companies
articles.snippet: Companies like Allergan, Valeant, Salix, Actavis and Medtronic are riding a wave of cheap debt and pent-up demand in a slew of recent acquisitions or attempted acquisitions.
articles.abstract: Companies like Allergan, Valeant, Salix, Actavis and Medtronic are riding a wave of cheap debt and pent-up demand in a slew of recent acquisitions or attempted acquisitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: A chain reaction of deal-making and acquisition talks is continuing to reshape the pharmaceutical industry, with a handful of big companies jostling to outmaneuver their competitors.

articles.headline: Hackers’ Attack Cracked 10 Financial Firms in Major Assault
articles.snippet: As the breadth and potential source of the attack on JPMorgan Chase became clearer, Washington officials urgently expressed concern about the potential for more serious attacks in the future.
articles.abstract: As the breadth and potential source of the attack on JPMorgan Chase became clearer, Washington officials urgently expressed concern about the potential for more serious attacks in the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: The huge cyberattack on JPMorgan Chase that touched more than 83 million households and businesses was one of the most serious computer intrusions into an American corporation. But it could have been much worse.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Nicole Perlroth and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: An Open Window for Insider Sales
articles.snippet: When the S.E.C. asks questions about certain financial filings, a company’s insiders have a chance to sell shares before other investors know of the issue.
articles.abstract: When the S.E.C. asks questions about certain financial filings, a company’s insiders have a chance to sell shares before other investors know of the issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Securities and Exchange Commission talks, company executives tend to listen.

articles.headline: For the Wolf of Luxury, a Chance to Be a Lamb
articles.snippet: With a new art museum and performance space, Bernard Arnault and LVMH are offering Paris a big gift — one that also has implications for the giver.
articles.abstract: With a new art museum and performance space, Bernard Arnault and LVMH are offering Paris a big gift — one that also has implications for the giver.
articles.lead_paragraph: High above the luxury shopping utopia that is the Avenue Montaigne in Paris, Bernard Arnault, the 65-year old chairman and chief executive of LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, was sitting in a wood-paneled conference room and smiling. Really smiling: eyes crinkled, teeth agleam. You might even say he was grinning.

articles.headline: Ebola’s Cultural Casualty: Hugs in Hands-On Liberia
articles.snippet: As Ebola ravages West Africa, Liberians are losing an integral part of their culture, in which the double-cheek kiss was once the standard greeting.
articles.abstract: As Ebola ravages West Africa, Liberians are losing an integral part of their culture, in which the double-cheek kiss was once the standard greeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — It is hard enough to push away family and friends, shunning an embrace or even a shake of the hand to protect yourself from Ebola.

articles.headline: Jean-Claude Duvalier Dies at 63; Ruled Haiti in Father’s Brutal Fashion
articles.snippet: Mr. Duvalier returned to Haiti in 2011 after a 25-year exile and continued to defend what human rights workers called one of the most oppressive governments in the Western Hemisphere.
articles.abstract: Mr. Duvalier returned to Haiti in 2011 after a 25-year exile and continued to defend what human rights workers called one of the most oppressive governments in the Western Hemisphere.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jean-Claude Duvalier, a former president of Haiti known as Baby Doc who ruled the country with a bloody brutality and then shocked it anew with a sudden return from a 25-year exile in 2011, died on Saturday in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. He was 63.

articles.headline: A Couple Gaining Independence, and Finding a Bond
articles.snippet: After a federal inquiry in Rhode Island turned the workplace of their repetitive jobs upside down, a couple with intellectual disabilities is marrying, learning to budget and adjusting to a new freedom.
articles.abstract: After a federal inquiry in Rhode Island turned the workplace of their repetitive jobs upside down, a couple with intellectual disabilities is marrying, learning to budget and adjusting to a new freedom.
articles.lead_paragraph: EAST PROVIDENCE, R.I. — A Sunday wedding that was months away, then weeks away, then days away, is now hours away, and there is so much still to do. The bride is panicking, and the groom is trying to calm her between anxious puffs of his cigarette.

articles.headline: Democrats Lean Heavily on PACs in Coordinated Push to Counter G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Democrats are more reliant than they have ever been on the very kind of big-money groups they have spent years trying to outlaw.
articles.abstract: Democrats are more reliant than they have ever been on the very kind of big-money groups they have spent years trying to outlaw.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the battle for the Senate tilting toward Republicans and President Obama’s approval ratings hovering near his all-time low, Democrats are more reliant than they have ever been on the very kind of big-money groups they have spent years trying to outlaw.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: Edgar Allan Poe’s Feud With Boston? Nevermore
articles.snippet: The author who mocked the Frog Pond will join Boston’s literary big fish with the unveiling of a statue in the city.
articles.abstract: The author who mocked the Frog Pond will join Boston’s literary big fish with the unveiling of a statue in the city.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Edgar Allan Poe had a love-hate relationship with the city of Boston.

articles.headline: Hewlett-Packard Is Said to Be Planning a Split of Businesses
articles.snippet: The company is expected to divide into two entities — one that consists of its PC business and another that is more enterprise-focused, people familiar with the matter said.
articles.abstract: The company is expected to divide into two entities — one that consists of its PC business and another that is more enterprise-focused, people familiar with the matter said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seeking a place for itself in a digital world increasingly dominated by mobile technology, Hewlett-Packard is on the verge of a sweeping reorganization, according to executives close to HP’s leadership.
articles.byline: By Quentin Hardy and David Gelles

articles.headline: The Washington Post Regains Its Place at the Table
articles.snippet: Jeff Bezos’s willingness to finance hiring new employees has created an atmosphere of confidence and financial stability supported by strong journalistic leadership.
articles.abstract: Jeff Bezos’s willingness to finance hiring new employees has created an atmosphere of confidence and financial stability supported by strong journalistic leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nothing in God’s creation is ever as good as it once was, but The Washington Post is coming pretty close.

articles.headline: Facebook’s Shuttle Bus Drivers Seek to Unionize
articles.snippet: Some of the drivers, who work for a contractor and put in 15-hour split shifts, are seeking representation by the Teamsters.
articles.abstract: Some of the drivers, who work for a contractor and put in 15-hour split shifts, are seeking representation by the Teamsters.
articles.lead_paragraph: They shuttle highly paid Facebook employees to and from the company’s headquarters in Silicon Valley, yet many say their pay is so low that they can’t afford to live in the area. Moreover, many complain that they start work around 6 a.m. and do not finish until 9 p.m., 15 hours later.

articles.headline: Hong Kong Wealth Gap on Display in Protests
articles.snippet: Dissatisfaction with a growing wealth gap in Hong Kong has helped fuel recent public demonstrations, which could shake the city’s immediate and long-term stability.
articles.abstract: Dissatisfaction with a growing wealth gap in Hong Kong has helped fuel recent public demonstrations, which could shake the city’s immediate and long-term stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The normally gridlocked thoroughfare in front of the main Lamborghini dealership here is now quiet and carless. Guests at the $600-a-night Mandarin Oriental hotel had to enter through a lowered metal security gate on a few recent evenings, and several jewelers and luxury handbag shops are temporarily shuttered.

articles.headline: Ebola Help for Sierra Leone Is Nearby, but Delayed on the Docks
articles.snippet: More than $140,000 worth of medical supplies have been locked inside a dented container at the port in Freetown, Sierra Leone, since Aug. 9.
articles.abstract: More than $140,000 worth of medical supplies have been locked inside a dented container at the port in Freetown, Sierra Leone, since Aug. 9.
articles.lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — It has been sitting idly on the docks for nearly two months: a shipping container packed with protective gowns, gloves, stretchers, mattresses and other medical supplies needed to help fight Sierra Leone’s exploding Ebola epidemic.

articles.headline: Technology Takes the Wheel
articles.snippet: By the end of the decade, many automakers will offer vehicles that can take control on the highway, even passing and exiting on their own.
articles.abstract: By the end of the decade, many automakers will offer vehicles that can take control on the highway, even passing and exiting on their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Google’s driverless car may still be a work in progress, but the potential for semiautonomous vehicles on American roads is no longer the stuff of science fiction.

articles.headline: A Smuggled Girl’s Odyssey of False Promises and Fear
articles.snippet: Cecilia, a 16-year-old Guatemalan seeking a better life in the United States, fell prey to “coyotes,” the smugglers who lure migrants, on a trip that devolved into outright abduction.
articles.abstract: Cecilia, a 16-year-old Guatemalan seeking a better life in the United States, fell prey to “coyotes,” the smugglers who lure migrants, on a trip that devolved into outright abduction.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL PARAÍSO, Guatemala — The smugglers advertised on the radio as spring bloomed into summer: “Do you want to live better? Come with me.”
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Frances Robles

articles.headline: An Obama Ally Parts With Him on War Powers
articles.snippet: Senator Tim Kaine told the president that if he intended to go to war with ISIS, he would have to ask Congress’s permission. The two have been battling ever since.
articles.abstract: Senator Tim Kaine told the president that if he intended to go to war with ISIS, he would have to ask Congress’s permission. The two have been battling ever since.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORANGE, Va. — In June, after he had written a scorching opinion article seeking to constrain the president’s unilateral power to make war, Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia, one of Barack Obama’s earliest supporters, buttonholed the commander in chief at the White House for what he called “a spirited discussion.”

articles.headline: To Reach China, LinkedIn Plays by Local Rules
articles.snippet: The professional social network’s Chinese-language version, which lacks certain features of Western versions, seems to have the tacit approval of China’s government.
articles.abstract: The professional social network’s Chinese-language version, which lacks certain features of Western versions, seems to have the tacit approval of China’s government.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For American technology companies from Microsoft to Facebook to Google, China is a difficult, even impossible, place to operate.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: If the Word ‘How’ Is Trademarked, Does This Headline Need a ™?
articles.snippet: An unlikely word, one intended to highlight superior methods, has become the center of a legal struggle between a management guru and a yogurt manufacturer.
articles.abstract: An unlikely word, one intended to highlight superior methods, has become the center of a legal struggle between a management guru and a yogurt manufacturer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Who owns How?

articles.headline: Ebola Victim’s Journey From Liberian War to Fight for Life in U.S.
articles.snippet: What began as a joyful reunion — refugees from African civil strife seeking to rebuild their lives in America — spiraled last week into a national health scare.
articles.abstract: What began as a joyful reunion — refugees from African civil strife seeking to rebuild their lives in America — spiraled last week into a national health scare.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The murderous civil war that terrorized Liberia from 1989 to 2003 left at least 5 percent of the population dead, and sent wave after wave of refugees to neighboring countries. To escape the ethnic and political turmoil, more than 700,000 fled from a nation that had barely two million residents when the conflict began.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Delivers Tacit Win to Gay Marriage
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court let stand appeals court rulings allowing same-sex marriage in five states in a move that may signal the inevitability of a nationwide right to such unions.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court let stand appeals court rulings allowing same-sex marriage in five states in a move that may signal the inevitability of a nationwide right to such unions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday let stand appeals court rulings allowing same-sex marriage in five states, a major surprise that could signal the inevitability of the right of same-sex marriage nationwide.
